[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary and phrasing (e.g., "ride Life's lists," "sown his wild oats") may impede modern readability.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, complex sentence structures (e.g., "They have the temperament...").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from discussing Italian influence to Reynolds' self-control (e.g., "It is hard to find...").
[STRUCTURE]: Minor repetition of themes (e.g., determination, artistic influences) without strong connective tissue.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, multi-clausal sentences may impede immediate clarity for casual readers.
[LEXICON]: Formal, elevated vocabulary (e.g., "dilated eye," "perfections of his sitters") assumes a sophisticated audience.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from discussing Reynolds’ flaws (e.g., "Lion Comique" analogy) to the Royal Academy’s history without clear bridging.
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential mention of the Foundling Hospital’s indirect role in the R.A.’s creation feels disconnected without elaboration.
[LOGIC]: Minor disjointedness between paragraphs on artistic philosophy and biographical anecdotes (e.g., Johnson/Garrick references vs. R.A. politics).

[LEXICON]: Archaisms (e.g., "faux pas," "turgid") may impede readability for modern readers.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, multi-clausal sentences (e.g., "He has found time...")

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between topics (e.g., art techniques → social life → deafness).
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential references (e.g., "The Club" introduction lacks context).
[LOGIC]: Chapter ends abruptly with unrelated apology about Royal Academy.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "Fortune could have given him nothing more..."), but no grammatical errors.

[STRUCTURE]: Minor jumps between biographical events and art critiques (e.g., Garrick reference feels slightly tangential).

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences with multiple nested clauses (e.g., "He sought for the colour of Rubens...").
[LEXICON]: Archaic phrasing (e.g., "had lowered the spirits," "well-merited obscurity") may slightly impede modern readability.

[TRANSITION]: Sudden shift from discussing artistic ideals to the statement "Artists tell us that painting should be no more than a harmony..." without clear contextual bridge.
[CLARITY]: Some critiques of Reynolds’ portraits (e.g., "The Age of Innocence") lack explicit connection to preceding analysis of his artistic goals.
